question.title: {"sections": [{"spans": [{"text": "What is the most extreme political hypocrisy?", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}]}

answer.content: {"sections": [{"spans": [{"text": "For several years, I\u2019ve taken unpopular stances in defending institutions of the United States that come under heavy criticism. These included defense of the ", "modifiers": {}}, {"text": "National Anthem when it was called a \u201cracist\u201d anthem of a \u201cracist\u201d country,", "modifiers": {"link": {"type": "answer", "aid": 101423448, "url": "https://www.quora.com/How-is-TakeAKnee-perceived-by-politically-conservative-communities-in-the-US/answer/Jon-Davis-10"}}}, {"text": " and more recently, defending the very institution of the police. In both cases, whether it\u2019s about kneeling during the anthem or claiming that the police are racist, the issue we deal with is ", "modifiers": {}}, {"text": "\u201csystemic racism.\u201d", "modifiers": {"bold": true}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "", "modifiers": {"image": "https://qph.fs.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-1129fa3ac0710e685de06d9534faf801", "height": 550, "width": 824, "master_url": "https://qph.fs.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-599f7031d8ae7228f8ad234eaf1e0868", "zoomable": true}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "image", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "\u201cSystemic racism\u201d isn't racism, as most of us understand it. It isn't when a person is treated differently because of their skin color. That\u2019s the definition we all used to believe.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "Racism is said to be \"systemic\" when the negative treatment doesn\u2019t come from an individual, but from the system itself. Think Jim Crow. Jim Crow was systemic racism because treating people differently because of race was literally written into the laws. The systems that existed were clearly and demonstrably systemic racism by design.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "", "modifiers": {"image": "https://qph.fs.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-f10fdb8c114dddc533c81ff40f9813d4", "height": 640, "width": 960, "master_url": "https://qph.fs.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-fdbf8064baf73692bfef4db90244d098", "zoomable": true}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "image", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "With systemic racism, you could have institutions filled with otherwise decent people, but because the rules are written in, it will do things that oppress or hold back certain people automatically. For example, Civil Rights was about fighting systemic racism, as in, if there is a rule on the books that is literally written to treat one race different from another, that\u2019s illegal. Once discovered, anyone could challenge it in a court of law and that rule will no longer be a rule.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "This was the purpose of Civil Rights. It provided the legal framework for fighting systemic racism, as in, if there is a rule on the books that is literally written to treat one race different from another, that\u2019s illegal. You can challenge it a court of law and that rule will no longer be a rule.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "That was the victory of the Civil Rights movement. It wasn\u2019t that we \u201cfixed racism\u201d. Such high minded ideals will never happen. So long as people themselves are different, someone will come to generalizations and not like them. I prefer that reality to one where we\u2019re all soulless robots. But Civil Rights did create a system whereby people can challenge unfair laws or organizational polices in courts and those organizations could be pressed to change. The organization continues to provide service to the community, but the rule that hurts people is removed. Whatever racism existed in the system is purged and racism itself is disincentivized throughout society. Win-Win, but it takes time.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "Not days or weeks, but at least a generation. You were born in a time where racism is considered very ugly. 99% of humanity going back tens of thousands of years... thought it was a survival tactic, and it worked. Be thankful for the times you live in, but radical change following every ideological whim will undermine whatever healthy progress we've thus far created.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "", "modifiers": {"image": "https://qph.fs.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-0e64f4fd74ceac34efeff099533f10f8", "height": 387, "width": 600, "master_url": "https://qph.fs.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-0e64f4fd74ceac34efeff099533f10f8"}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "image", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "This process, beginning with abolition, continuing through the Civil Right's era, has already been going on now for several succeeding generations. The incentives to be racist, either personally or instructionally are so bad that trying it openly will cost you. In that sort of culture, racism dies.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "Yea.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "That\u2019s why racism is the lowest it\u2019s ever been\u2026 well, that\u2019s not true. Things were better around 2009, but that's another story for a different day. But in general, the great crime of our education and information dissemination systems is the failure of the average American to know that we are the least racist today than we have ever been, or even that America, when measured against almost anywhere else, is one of the least racist places in the world.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "", "modifiers": {"image": "https://qph.fs.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-3dc3dc57d37d3e59d5bd0b36073df68d", "height": 664, "width": 1536, "master_url": "https://qph.fs.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-53fe39d98c020e3c1b31d4554c714983", "zoomable": true}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "image", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "That is to say that while finding individual examples of racism isn\u2019t very hard, it\u2019s hard to say that all Americas are racist. Finding an example of a neo-nazi or member of the KKK isn't hard. I mean, it's very hard to find one in person, but the media is very good at making sure you see the few who come out. Did you know that the KKK only consists of about 7,000 members, and that they are mostly just small feuding groups spread across the country with no influence at all? That's not a conservative stance. That's actually sourced from the Southern Poverty Law Center's hate group tracker, and the SPLC has anything but a history of being fair in that regard. That they could only prove about 7,000 disparate people should say something about how much attention they receive.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "", "modifiers": {"image": "https://qph.fs.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-7ddb1cf39869e0e10e078bc86a3f5476", "height": 573, "width": 864, "master_url": "https://qph.fs.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-29c151618b65871b30f4a84236b25046", "zoomable": true}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "image", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "But this is also racism, of the kind that you very rarely see outside of a few select sources.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "", "modifiers": {"image": "https://qph.fs.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-c9467b57c5b12cf9a60af99f413b1995", "height": 415, "width": 770, "master_url": "https://qph.fs.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-5a114ba7a3462e1a95d580bab03ad39a", "zoomable": true}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "image", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "Finding examples of racism that goes the other way isn't difficult either. Seeing things like \"Die Whites Die\", \"All White People are Racist\", undermines the notion that racism is a purely white problem.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "", "modifiers": {"image": "https://qph.fs.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-c659d766ca2e01c8f7981585f206e921", "height": 480, "width": 640, "master_url": "https://qph.fs.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-84c820bfd67f00f7b7725ccfaeb97b76", "zoomable": true}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "image", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "To say nothing of events that should outrage everyone, like the kidnapping and torture of a mentally handicapped man, tied, beaten, and forced to drink from a toilet while denouncing Donald Trump by four black kidnappers. They\u2019re bigotry was so normalized that they broadcast it over Facebook. How normal do you have to think a hate crime is to post it live to Social Media, not realizing this will probably have consequences? Why we aren\u2019t talking about this daily still boggles my mind.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "", "modifiers": {"image": "https://qph.fs.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-479f64ad9cb737b86753a049ca4c37a0", "height": 316, "width": 474, "master_url": "https://qph.fs.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-479f64ad9cb737b86753a049ca4c37a0"}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "image", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "(", "modifiers": {"italic": true}}, {"text": "Four charged with hate crimes for torturing mentally disabled teen on Facebook Live", "modifiers": {"italic": true, "link": {"type": "url", "url": "https://www.nydailynews.com/news/national/torture-attack-illinois-teen-not-racially-motivated-cops-article-1.2935818"}}}, {"text": ")", "modifiers": {"italic": true}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "Regardless of these events, or the existence of groups who are hateful, that doesn't define a population of over three hundred million people. We've been told for decades against the evils of overgeneralizing whole populations. Why does that rule apply to some groups, and not to America itself?", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "Measuring objectively, it\u2019s very difficult to prove that racism is actually a defining characteristic of our country. In fact, the more you look elsewhere (save for those special utopian European cities where all the tourists go) you see that America is far more racially tolerant than is normal. That is to say that the presence of racism somewhere in a population does not make the population racist, just like a person of a particular color being in a gang doesn\u2019t make everyone who looks like him gang members. I assume I don\u2019t need to illustrate this point further.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "But that\u2019s exactly what we\u2019ve done. For reasons that are too extensive for this letter, we\u2019ve taken examples of some people\u2019s racism, mostly a small handful of white supremacists spread across the country in tiny pockets of discontentment, added the fact that racial economic and social disparity still exists, and ignored all other possible explanations for why that could happen, and jumped to the conclusion that white supremacy built and perpetuates a system specifically designed to disenfranchise people of color.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "", "modifiers": {"image": "https://qph.fs.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-e641fb203b01b06b871639ca00aa7695", "height": 349, "width": 580, "master_url": "https://qph.fs.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-e641fb203b01b06b871639ca00aa7695"}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "image", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "What other explanations exist? I\u2019ve written a massive answer on answering just that question: ", "modifiers": {}}, {"text": "Jon Davis's answer to Why do many white people pretend racism does not exist?", "modifiers": {"link": {"type": "answer", "aid": 82209257, "url": "https://www.quora.com/Why-do-many-white-people-pretend-racism-does-not-exist/answer/Jon-Davis-10"}}}, {"text": " There, you\u2019ll see many arguments for why there is racial disparity in America that are not caused by racism. And the people I sourced for that aren\u2019t other white people. They are black conservatives who look to more grounded explanations for why things are as they are in their communities than the simple excuse that the racism of someone who doesn\u2019t live anywhere near them, has no power over them, and has no interest in their lives, is still responsible for most of the disparity in 2020. That\u2019s a massive answer, so if you\u2019re curious, go there, but we\u2019re not going to talk about it, here. What we are going to talk about is how, in spite of many, many well documented examples demonstrating why black disparity exists that have nothing to do with racism, it is believed that whole vital institutions in America are said to be systemically racist.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "For example, let\u2019s start the police. Currently, we\u2019re just coming down from a months long struggle that culminated with violence towards police and calls for abolishing them everywhere. Why? Because the police, not just some police officers, but the entire institution of policing in the United States is said to be racist at its core.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "", "modifiers": {"image": "https://qph.fs.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-1367a502732429b0fd35f1fa603005b3", "height": 460, "width": 788, "master_url": "https://qph.fs.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-9be554a64cb0dcbf7b0a9a03fd4f0e62", "zoomable": true}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "image", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "The police, and the justice system itself, are considered to be systemically racist because more blacks are imprisoned than whites per capita. Individual high profile incidents shine a bright blazing beacon on the problem, and point to a system that makes cops actually racist, specifically targeting blacks for arrest, and even killing, some going so far as to accuse the American police forces as literally guilty of black genocide. Those aren\u2019t true. There have been numerous studies done that show that blacks and whites, when in the same situations are treated the same by cops, such as police shootings. In fact, studies have shown that white police officers are less likely to kill minorities than other whites in similar situations. ", "modifiers": {}}, {"text": " ", "modifiers": {"citation": {"target": {"type": "url", "url": "https://www.npr.org/2019/07/26/745731839/new-study-says-white-police-officers-are-not-more-likely-to-shoot-minority-suspe"}, "title": "New Study Says White Police Officers Are Not More Likely To Shoot Minority Suspects", "index": 1, "unique_id": "MTrzn"}}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "No, the issue is that there are more crimes committed per capita, and particularly violent crimes among those populations than others. That is the disparity, and the criminal justice system should reflect it. Solving for ", "modifiers": {}}, {"text": "why ", "modifiers": {"italic": true}}, {"text": "that happens is something I already addressed ", "modifiers": {}}, {"text": "here", "modifiers": {"link": {"type": "answer", "aid": 82209257, "url": "https://www.quora.com/Why-do-many-white-people-pretend-racism-does-not-exist/answer/Jon-Davis-10"}}}, {"text": ". Simply put, bad policy, which people voted for, that led to destructive unintended consequences on a population like increasing fatherlessness in the home, the decline of education standards, shipping jobs overseas, or piling tens of thousands of people in a few block area (the Projects) was a recipe for the predictable disaster that has fallen on black cities. And it was predicted. People said that we would see a rise in crime and other vices and we did. It's not an aspect of black culture. That is not a natural consequence of a people that gave us Frederick Douglass, the Harlem Renaissance, and Thomas Sowell. It's a consequence of bad policy, and of politicians who refuse to take responsibility for saying, \"Our ideas may have meant well, but failed and now we have do the hard thing, and take away programs that people have grown dependent upon. It will cost us votes, but it's the right thing to do.\" Rather than do that hard thing, those same people blame other people's racism, and the cops.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "Because there is a demonstrable difference in the outcomes one race experiences, regardless of the initiating events that led to that difference, it is said that there is inequality and when race is involved in that, it is racism. Too often, actually reviewing the specifics of a case undermines the argument that a specific person\u2019s white racism was to blame, in the first place. People rioted and destroyed whole cities because of that belief, but the facts don't add up. A thorough look into the history Michael Brown, famous for \"Hands up; Don't shoot\" is a case study in how an incident can be turned 180 degrees from what actually happened to what people were protesting about. Whatever, the case, that and all the other incidents are still viewed as proof of America's white racism and of the police. The racism is built into the system, regardless of the individual cop in question. Where no individual\u2019s explicit racism can be proven, but some racial inequality exists\u2026 then the cause is systemic racism.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "", "modifiers": {"image": "https://qph.fs.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-8969e2987b964fc247ff08b4fae2c7eb", "height": 682, "width": 1024, "master_url": "https://qph.fs.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-5aac9ac05f23310cb0cd75c0036ff115", "zoomable": true}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "image", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "Put differently, the arguments of systemic racism say that whether or not racism exists in individuals, it exists at the organizational level. This is particularly true if those organizations and institutions were built during more racist times, having inherited the racism of their founders, who subtly built the racism into the system.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "It really doesn\u2019t matter what events have transpired since then, what reforms have been made, even cases where racist people were purged, or racist policies stricken either by an act of law, or by the institution itself voluntarily. The extremist view that is gaining significant wind is that an organization that in any way held a different standard of ethics than we do today, be that racism, sexism, or otherwise, is irredeemable and must atone or be abolished for past crimes. If the institution existed during a time more racist than today, they are part of whatever problems exist for racial minorities at present and therefore\u2026 racist. Worse still, any greater institution, such as the United States itself, which doesn\u2019t ", "modifiers": {}}, {"text": "solve ", "modifiers": {"italic": true}}, {"text": "the problem as the accusers see fit (not being \u201canti-racist\u201d) then they are racist as well. This was why Collin Kaepernick\u2019s is now famous, as demonstrated in own statements when he refused to stand for the flag of a racist nation. To quote him:", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "\"I am not going to stand up to show pride in a flag for a country that oppresses black people and people of color,\" Kaepernick told NFL Media in an exclusive interview after the game. \"To me, this is bigger than football and it would be selfish on my part to look the other way. There are bodies in the street and people getting paid leave and getting away with murder.\"", "modifiers": {}}, {"text": "[1]", "modifiers": {"link": {"type": "answer", "aid": 101423448, "url": "https://www.quora.com/How-is-TakeAKnee-perceived-by-politically-conservative-communities-in-the-US/answer/Jon-Davis-10"}}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": true, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "", "modifiers": {"image": "https://qph.fs.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-22fb0cee665e4ab386a8ccd1f03bbbe2", "height": 744, "width": 992, "master_url": "https://qph.fs.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-453d8593e7ed9de40b5aa6d86323fc6c", "zoomable": true}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "image", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "Here\u2019s an interesting case to to consider. In 2002, there was a lawsuit which held eight American companies responsible for reparations for blacks in America because of links to slavery over 150 years prior\u2026 to the tune of ", "modifiers": {}}, {"text": "$1.4 trillion dollars", "modifiers": {"italic": true}}, {"text": ".", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "A prayer on a Brooklyn street preceded the filing of an unprecedented $1.4 trillion lawsuit against eight major corporations alleged to have profited from their historical ties to the slave trade more than 137 years ago.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": true, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "Claiming to represent all of the United States' 35 million African-Americans, New York slave reparations activist Deadria Farmer-Paellmann named Aetna Inc., CSX Corp. and FleetBoston Financial Corp., among others, as unjustly profiting from the slave trade before the Civil War ended in 1865.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": true, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "\"We are going to finally hold corporations accountable for the crimes against humanity that they've committed against my ancestors,\" Farmer-Paellmann told reporters Tuesday.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": true, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "(Eric Shawn, 2002)", "modifiers": {}}, {"text": " ", "modifiers": {"citation": {"target": {"type": "url", "url": "https://www.foxnews.com/story/lawsuit-chases-companies-tied-to-slavery"}, "title": "Lawsuit Chases Companies Tied to Slavery", "index": 2, "unique_id": "suhyf"}}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": true, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "Later in the article, more light is given on the fact that the law firm Farmer-Paellmann was the same firm who won over $8 Billion from Swiss banks who held Nazi assets taken from Jews before and during World War II. They base the legitimacy of their 2002 claims on the fact that companies like Aetna had already previously acknowledged that shortly after its founding it insured the lives of slaves in a 2000 acknowledgment expressing their deep regret over any participation at all in this deplorable practice. Likewise, CSX was placed on the list because slave labor was produced to build railways. Beyond that, companies such as New York Life, AIG, J.P. Morgan Chase, Wachovia, and FleetBoston also made the list.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "Wachovia, it needs to be highlighted, didn\u2019t even exist during slavery. It was founded in 1879. They were held responsible for the actions of two companies they purchased in 1991, the Bank of Charleston and Georgia Railroad and Banking Companies, both of whom owned slaves prior to the Civil War. Yet the burden was pushed to Wachovia, somehow. That\u2019s interesting, because now Wachovia itself no longer exists. Following the collapse of the banking industry in 2008, Wachovia was purchased by Wells Fargo. That said, the argument that Wachovia had any wealth it owed to slavery following 2008, or the numerous other recessions it survived, to say nothing of the Great Depression which preceded it, is a tough sell, particularly when its sin came from two other companies it bought years prior. But give it about 10 more years, and we\u2019ll see if anyone starts looking to Wells Fargo for their slave owning past, by way of the defunct Wachovia, by way of two companies which stopped existing in the 1990s. This is to say that at no point will the apologies or the forms of reparations be enough, so long as someone somewhere has not achieved prosperity and someone somewhere can be linked to some ancestral form of victimhood. ", "modifiers": {}}, {"text": " ", "modifiers": {"citation": {"target": {"type": "url", "url": "https://money.cnn.com/2005/06/02/news/fortune500/wachovia_slavery/"}, "title": "Wachovia apologizes for ties to slavery", "index": 3, "unique_id": "NzWPj"}}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "This case ended with the expected failure, however numerous companies were forced into some action. J.P. Morgan Chase apologizing for some tie to slavery and the creation of a $5 million scholarship program in 2005. But it didn\u2019t stop with just that case.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "So that we understand the situation, eight companies were forced in 2002 to defend the notion that they are currently responsible to pay for their participation, or rather, their existence in the vaguest of definitions, in normal market activities of the time, from a 150 years prior\u2026 for 1.4 trillion dollars. A rational thinking person would argue that a company which traded slaves prior to the Civil War is doubtfully still profiting from that individual choice. Given the undeniable destruction of the South\u2019s economy from the Civil War, a Great Depression, and numerous recessions since, it\u2019s hard to say that slavery is why these companies remain successful and why they hold some burden of guilt. They don\u2019t. It\u2019s not reasonable.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "While this case sounded ridiculous, this \u201coriginal sin\u201d outlook of judging and punishing today\u2019s institutions based on the events of hundreds of years ago is a modern basis for critical race theory. Collin Kaerpernick\u2019s now famous kneeling has awarded him millions based on this idea, but ", "modifiers": {}}, {"text": "#takeaknee", "modifiers": {"link": {"type": "url", "url": "https://www.facebook.com/hashtag/takeaknee?__cft__[0]=AZV0_c-WEWJq5O3X0SflKsSxeMvgPXDypyHIMJJRs_e6G1pYH8quno3YWtg0PH1OtW5sW41ENhn4e9mAz_Z53cWCbB8VZH4eAZUU-GZRDjo9ogthmkntagLfPLQd08CjxgqXouMxmiFklC3G8U0w86TOuQ4jGHZSQZFb7hIX850IJxNTm94WTWV1PGQBUOuayFo&__tn__=*NK-R"}}}, {"text": " wasn\u2019t even the worst case of original sin critical race theory in action. For that, we should look to the New York Times\u2019 1619 Project.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "", "modifiers": {"image": "https://qph.fs.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-0a1103dcccefe176b8ae1a459904b333", "height": 420, "width": 640, "master_url": "https://qph.fs.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-aa91cd2bda15acfb850ed1a12c5f45e9", "zoomable": true}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "image", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "Immediately after the Trump/Russia collusion story fell through, the New York Times\u2019 very intentionally shifted to a narrative of America\u2019s troubling racist past and it\u2019s implications in today\u2019s world.", "modifiers": {}}, {"text": " ", "modifiers": {"citation": {"target": {"type": "url", "url": "https://www.washingtonexaminer.com/opinion/columnists/new-york-times-chief-outlines-coverage-shift-from-trump-russia-to-trump-racism"}, "title": "New York Times chief outlines coverage shift: From Trump-Russia to Trump racism", "index": 4, "unique_id": "AapFZ"}}}, {"text": " 1619 Project\u2019s stated aim is to \u201creframe the country\u2019s history by placing the consequences of slavery and the contributions of black Americans at the very center of [the United States'] national narrative.\" What it actually does is attempt to paint the America which exists today as being truly founded in 1619 with the first slave trade in what would become the United States, and that America\u2019s legacy, its very essence, is one built on the backs of slaves. That\u2019s it.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "horizontal-rule", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "Okay, now that we\u2019ve laid out what systemic racism is, who it affects, and how it is an inescapable and unforgivable burden of guilt on the accused\u2026 we need to talk about the hypocrisy.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "If racism was ever part of the picture in the history of an organization, then it is forever marked by that fact. Right?", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "So, where does the hypocrisy come in?", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "Because the people who say these things the most, are Democrats trying to elect Joe Biden as President of the United States.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "", "modifiers": {"image": "https://qph.fs.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-f5f4818c6691c61cf983875ea109be72", "height": 907, "width": 1440, "master_url": "https://qph.fs.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-dc5adb4125d515c2990601b656b56242", "zoomable": true}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "image", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "Let\u2019s keep this idea of systemic racism, original sin guilt of America as demonstrated by the 1619 Project, and all the other examples I\u2019ve pointed out, and ask why they don\u2019t apply to some people.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "In 1977, Biden was a U.S. senator in Delaware. ADOS communities and individuals that defied Jim Crow laws often were murdered or thrown in prison.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": true, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "By the time Joe Biden started his political career his worldview was molded in a time of legalized racial discrimination so he quite naturally wanted to continue the legacy of that American institution of Jim Crow not only by tradition but it helped him and his progeny as well, so he did.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": true, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "From the first time he was elected as a Senator of Delaware in 1973 all the way up to 2009 and still continues to show us that he has never been an ally to Black Americans (ADOS), the only reason Jim Crow Joe is even running for president again, is because people have this perception of \u2018uncle joe\u2019 largely because he was Obama\u2019s VP.", "modifiers": {}}, {"text": " ", "modifiers": {"citation": {"target": {"type": "url", "url": "https://medium.com/@taqwalee3/why-we-call-him-jim-crow-joe-biden-3f611636c389"}, "title": "Why We Call Him Jim Crow Joe Biden", "index": 7, "unique_id": "brXcX"}}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": true, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "That sounds very clearly like critical race theory applied in a place it rarely is -- the left.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "Looking at Biden\u2019s legacy, he has worked as part of the Democratic Party, where blacks have seen a reduction in living standards, harsher conditions, more death from violent crime, increased criminalization, for nearly five decades. That is the party that Joe Biden has been a leader of for nearly half a century without it getting better for the people it claims to represent the most.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "Getting off Biden for a while, maybe we should revisit the Democrats and their history, again, keeping in mind the inescapable guilt inherit to arguments of systemic racism.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "", "modifiers": {"image": "https://qph.fs.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-60fcee54829063ff9178b16de8e2b77f", "height": 873, "width": 1201, "master_url": "https://qph.fs.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-1d121f45d1175a035ca5fbee7fd58014", "zoomable": true}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "image", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "The Democratic party is directly responsible for writing the darkest pages of American history. Three points are generally given as proof of this switch:", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "In order to compete in the South, Republicans pandered to white racists in the sixties.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "ordered-list", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "Angry racist Democrats left their party & joined the Republicans after the Civil Rights act of 1964.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "ordered-list", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "This was all part of \u201cthe Southern Strategy\u201d, and ever since, the Republicans have dominated the South.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "ordered-list", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "These facts are all incorrect.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "First, it assumes that the Democratic Party could evolve to no longer be racist, but Southerners themselves could not. \u201cYou\u2019re from Georgia, and you\u2019re white. MacMillan, a former Air Force One steward:", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "\u201cI\u2019ll have those ni**ers voting Democratic for 200 years.\u201d", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": true, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "He also called the Civil Rights Act of 1957 the \u201cni**er bill\u201d to Senatorial colleagues and said of appointing African-American judge Thurgood Marshall to the Supreme Court:", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "\u201cSon, when I appoint a ni**er to the court, I want everyone to know he\u2019s a ni**er.\u201d", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": true, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "So\u2026 it seems not all the racist Democrats fled to the Republican Party. At least one stayed on as President. That said, given the \u201cswitch\u201d from a supremacist outlook to one of patronage, which in hindsight unironically achieved the same conditions for those involved, it left anyone consistently believing that people should just be free to prosper on their own merit rather than being judged based on the color of their skin suddenly and miraculously going from \u201c", "modifiers": {}}, {"text": "for black equality\u201d ", "modifiers": {"italic": true}}, {"text": "to \u201c", "modifiers": {}}, {"text": "not doing enough for blacks\u201d ", "modifiers": {"italic": true}}, {"text": "to ", "modifiers": {}}, {"text": "\u201cthe real white supremacists.\u201d", "modifiers": {"italic": true}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "All that to say that the Democratic Party cannot escape it\u2019s own history by passing the blame on to conservatives and Republicans. And they can\u2019t pretend that suddenly deciding they speak for the downtrodden absolves them from the responsibility of being most responsible of the problems they blame on others.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "horizontal-rule", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "While this answer appears to be a scathing indictment of the Democratic Party and Joe Biden, it actually isn\u2019t.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "It\u2019s illustrating a point.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "If many of you believe as you say you say believe, that systemic racism is an inescapable sin, that the consequences of history upon which an institution is founded are to forever define the innate character of that institution and all within it, then the Democratic Party is the most irredeemable institution in all of American history. If reparations for crimes of generations past are to be paid, it is not America\u2019s debt to be paid, but the Democrats. No one should kneel through the American anthem or call the abolition of the police if they have not already lobbied for the banning the Democratic Party, first. If America is a racist country because of it\u2019s founders, or the times in which it was formed, or racist things it has done in the past, and nothing that has happened since matters at all, then what does that make the Democratic party? If America, or the police, white people, modern companies who bought old companies, or anyone else holds a candle of guilt, and that that guilt should burn their reputation forever, then the Democrats are unpardonable inferno.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "If America can\u2019t be forgiven, then the Democratic Party has no right to exist.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "And Joe Biden?
